The Secretary of the Interior may permit the use of lands and facilities for film or TV projects if it won't harm the resources. Fees must be paid to the Secretary for the permit, ensuring a fair return to the government. The Secretary can establish fees for permits based on factors like the number of people on site, duration of activities, and location in special use areas. The Secretary may charge a fee for permits based on factors like the number of people, duration of activities, and location in special use areas. The fee can be reduced for activities that provide educational benefits. The Secretary can also require bonding or insurance to protect the interests of the United States. Regulations implementing this subsection must be issued within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Within 3 years of enactment, the Secretary will review and update regulations. Fees will be collected for filming involving advertisements, models, or potential resource damage. Other filming activities not listed are exempt from fees. The prohibition on fees for activities identified in the regulations will cease upon the effective date of new regulations. Amounts collected as fees will be available for expenditure without further appropriation and will follow the Recreational Fee Demonstration Program guidelines. Violators of the regulations may face fines according to title 18, United States Code. Violators of the regulations may face fines or imprisonment for up to 6 months, or both, and must pay all costs of the proceedings. The section and regulations will be effective 180 days after the enactment of the Act, with the Secretary's authority to issue regulations effective immediately. The House of Representatives passed the Act on September 15, 1998. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
